DOC.TEXT: After a bitter, seven-month battle, Unicorp Canada Corp. and partner Cara Operations have abandoned their bid for the world's largest doughnut-shop chain, Dunkin' Donuts Inc. DD Acquisitions Corp., a partnership between Unicorp's Kingsbridge Capital Group merchant bank subsidiary and Cara, said it intends to tender its Dunkin' Donuts shares to Allied-Lyons PLC, the British food company that made a rival bid last month. Dunkin' Donuts has accepted Allied-Lyons' bid of $47.25 per share, or a total of $325 million, in cash. Kingsbridge President Earl Rotman said DD Acquisition had bought 860,000 Dunkin' Donuts shares at an average of $34 each and will gain $11.4 million by tendering. Unicorp Canada Corp. and Cara Operations Ltd. launched their assault in June, offering $43 per share for a minimum 50.1 percent of Dunkin' Donuts' 6.85 million shares. The offer was increased to $45 in August. Allied-Lyons' surprise bid was welcomed by management of the chain, which is based in Randolph, Mass. Dunkin' Donuts had waged a fight against Unicorp that included the adoption of a poison-pill takeover defense in May. By tendering to Allied-Lyons, Unicorp suffered its second major defeat this year, having failed to buy the Montreal-based Steinberg Inc. grocery chain.
